The Bahrain Courts have been instructed to avoid giving sentences of imprisonment whenever possible. ^ It has been found that since living conditions here became difficult many pauper offenders are in fact glad to be sentenced to confinement in the Fort where they are well and expensively fed and do not have to work hard. His hair is shaved off on admission ana he is taken to the Record Office where he is photographed an his description recorded. T YPES OF IMPRISONMENT . There are two types of imprisonment:- i) Rigorous, in which the prisoner is chained by two lengths of chain, one on eachside of the bodv running from a riveted shackle o * 1 ' 1 ankle to a web belt round the waist. It entails eight hours work per day, quarrying stone, making mats or weaving sail cloth. ii) Simple, in which the prisoner is not chained and is only required to do light work such as sweeping and cleaning cells, gardening etc.. SICK PARADE. A daily sick parade is held attended by a State M edical^Officer. If it is necessary for a prisoner to be detained in the Government Hospital a sentry is provided. Other health arrangements are the provision of a daily bath, a piece of soap being issued to each2. prisoner for this purpose, and the hair of all prisoners is shaved monthly. CELLS. The cells are fitted with doors and one ^ window. The dimensions of each cell arel2' x 9 x 10'. Each cell contains one, two or three prisoners according to the total number of persons detained. Terms of imprisonment of prisoners sentenced by the Bahrain Court are assessed on the Islamic Calendar and those of prisoners sentenced by the court of H.M.B's Political Agent by the Gregorian Calendar. REMISSION AND DISCHARGE. Prisoners sentenced to terms of imprisonment of six months or more are given three days remission for each month of sentence, provided that the prisoner is of good behaviour. physicalDescription.extent: The file is arranged chronologically from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 44; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 1-18; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: The file consists of correspondence and notes relating to Bahrain State jails and the employment of prisoners at the Political Agency. The correspondence is between the Adviser to the Government of Bahrain (Charles Dalrymple Belgrave), the Political Agency at Bahrain, the Political Residency in the Persian Gulf, and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Commonwealth Relations, Pakistan.The file covers several matters, including:a lack of availability of prisoners for working at the Political Agency;plans for relaying the Agency tennis court;a Bahrain Government request to purchase prisoner uniforms from the Government of Pakistan;rules for treatment of prisoners, including supplementary rules for European prisoners.Folios 38-40 are internal office notes.
